history.content:
I think Garcia is awesome and one of the best cs professors I had, but I don't recommend putting your life on hold waiting until he teaches it. So many reall great upper-div classes (161, 162, 152, etc.) can't really be appreciated until you take 61C and you can miss out if you decide to push your schedule a semester back waiting on a professor that might end up switching at the last minute once again. If you know you don't want to branch off into systems, computer architecture, all that lower level stuff, and just want to take 61C to fulfill requirements and have a good professor, then feel free to wait though.

That's just my recommendation. I encourage you to watch some of Garcia's old 61C webcasts (they should be on youtube) and make the decision for yourself. Other than lectures, office hours, and exams, he won't really be active in other areas of the course, normally taken care of by the rest of the course staff. If you don't go to office hours and only attend lectures, you miss pretty much most of what I thought made him a really great professor.

Weaver is a pretty passionate professor. I heard he wants to do some really cool things for the course, which is something the course could really use to better attract more student interest in 61c concepts/areas. It might not be a bad idea to actually ask him about his plans via email (I've only heard about them from my fellow staff members).

source: former 61c student and current 61c TA (won't be around next semester unfortunately).

~~

just for a different opinion: 

I waited for Garcia to be teaching, and that ended up not being a great experience. It was fine, but his teaching style was not great for me, so I kind of regretted doing it. I am not sure 61C would have been for me with a different prof (it is my least favorite class at Berkeley), but for me personally his class was not all it was talked up to be.

Specifically:

  • He is really passionate, but really busy. At the time he had one hour of office hours for all the things he was teaching/overseeing and that was just not enough. I quickly gave up on trying bc there were just so many different people who needed attention during this short spot. 
  • He goes very fast. He countered this by having lots of information on the slides and printing the slides to hand out at lecture. This is great if it works for how you learn best! But for me, I really need the pace of the lecture to be slow enough that I can write notes and process, otherwise I have a hard time understanding. I ended up going over the webcasts slowly with lots of pausing, but this ended up taking a lot of time, and lecture was kind of a waste of time. He was also trying to make the lectures interactive, but I was not able to take advantage of this bc I was just not able to keep up.

I think Garcia is awesome and one of the best cs professors I had, but I don't recommend putting your life on hold waiting until he teaches it. So many reall great upper-div classes (161, 162, 152, etc.) can't really be appreciated until you take 61C and you can miss out if you decide to push your schedule a semester back waiting on a professor that might end up switching at the last minute once again. If you know you don't want to branch off into systems, computer architecture, all that lower level stuff, and just want to take 61C to fulfill requirements and have a good professor, then feel free to wait though.

That's just my recommendation. I encourage you to watch some of Garcia's old 61C webcasts (they should be on youtube) and make the decision for yourself. Other than lectures, office hours, and exams, he won't really be active in other areas of the course, normally taken care of by the rest of the course staff. If you don't go to office hours and only attend lectures, you miss pretty much most of what I thought made him a really great professor.

Weaver is a pretty passionate professor. I heard he wants to do some really cool things for the course, which is something the course could really use to better attract more student interest in 61c concepts/areas. It might not be a bad idea to actually ask him about his plans via email (I've only heard about them from my fellow staff members).

source: former 61c student and current 61c TA (won't be around next semester unfortunately).

Hi,

I have been planning to take CS61C in the upcoming Spring semester because I heard Dan Garcia is an awesome professor. However, I just found out today that Nicholas Weaver and Gerald Friedland are teaching it next semester. Would anyone recommend waiting to take it when Professor Garcia teaches it? What have people experienced with these other two professors?

Thanks,
Mihir
history.subject: CS61C Spring 2017
